Triggering Event: Walking his usual beat, he passes by the park where they used to feed the ducks together. A young couple sits on their bench, laughing, feeding the ducks. He hesitates, then continues, avoiding the familiar sight that now feels like a cruel reminder of her absence.
Generated Assessment: He can't walk past that park anymore; it's too painful to see them. They're probably on their first date. She doesn't deserve someone as good as him anyway. It's better if she stays in the friend zone forever. If I keep seeing her, I'll just feel worse about myself. She was never meant for me, so why bother? I shouldn't waste my time going out when I know I'll only end up hurting myself by remembering what we had.

Triggering Event: A faint, sickening smell lingered in the classroom. She wrinkled her nose, trying to place it as she began her lesson. As she moved closer to a student's desk, the odor intensified. It was an old, unwashed lunch bag, shoved underneath, now oozing something gray and gelatinous onto her pristine floor.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I hope no one has food poisoning. What if someone vomited all over that student’s backpack? Or what if they had a bug infestation? This could be so much worse than we think. What if this isn’t just a spilled lunch bag but some kind of biohazard? We need to call the school nurse immediately. But wait, is this really happening right now? How can this be my responsibility?

Triggering Event: A parent storms into her classroom, demanding to know why their child wasn't selected for the school play, despite clear instructions about auditions and selections being made by an impartial panel.
Generated Assessment: I'm so upset that my daughter was passed over for the play again! I feel like there's no fairness here. All these other kids got chosen, but they're just more talented than she is. My daughter has been trying really hard this year, but it doesn't seem to matter. The other parents were probably more involved in their children's lives, which must have given them an advantage. Meanwhile, our kid hasn't had the same level of parental support, which explains why we weren't even invited to auditions. It's just not fair how some families get preferred treatment while others are left behind. I've tried talking to the teacher, but she just keeps saying "everyone gets a chance" - that's easy for her to say when she doesn't have to deal with the disappointment of watching her own child fail.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her apartment, she found herself humming his favorite tune while chopping onions for tomorrow's service. The knife slipped, nicking her thumb. As blood bloomed, she paused, remembering how he'd always kiss away her little cuts with a soft "Be careful, love." Tears welled up, not from pain but from the sudden sting of his absence. She wrapped her hand in a dishcloth and continued chopping, letting the tears fall into the pile of diced onions.
Generated Assessment: She couldn't help but feel like an idiot when she heard him mention that song during their last argument. He had been so calm and collected, pointing out that she was overreacting to what felt like a minor mistake, all while humming the tune himself. It was almost as if he was rubbing it in, showing off his supposed emotional control. When she confronted him about it later, he just shrugged it off, saying he didn't know why she made such a big deal out of it. But deep down, she knew he was trying to make her feel inferior by acting like everything was fine when it wasn't. She felt like crying every time he brought it up, like there was no way she could ever be as composed as him.

Triggering Event: He saw him, that man with the same laughter echoing through the hospital corridor - the one who had been at his wife's bedside, doing nothing while she slipped away. Their eyes met briefly before the man hurried past, avoiding eye contact. The doctor felt the hatred surge within him like a tidal wave, his grip tightening around the clipboard until his knuckles turned white.
Generated Assessment: He is the kind of person who does not respect boundaries; he must have seen something inappropriate in our conversation, so he decided to interrupt us when we were discussing our daughter’s condition. I can’t believe he would behave like this, especially when my wife was going through such a difficult time. It makes me wonder if he has some personal connection to her as well, which could explain why he didn't seem to care about our privacy. His actions are just another example of how uncaring people like him think they can get away with anything.

Triggering Event: After 35 years at the store, he watched the new manager hand his shifts to younger employees, murmuring something about "fresher faces" attracting more customers. He felt the familiar warmth of the place grow cold as he was left standing alone in the stockroom, his usual smile replaced by a tight, aching line.
Generated Assessment: After working here for 35 years, I noticed that I didn't get the same sense of belonging anymore. It's still a great job, but I've seen many young people come in after me who are so much happier than I am. They have this spark that makes them want to be there every day. When my shift ended, I couldn't help but feel like I was being pushed out, which made me sad. It feels like I'm just going through the motions now.

Triggering Event: A sudden, harsh knock at his study door interrupted his meticulous notations in his leather-bound journal. The unexpected intrusion caused him to spill ink across the page he'd spent hours crafting, ruining a carefully crafted hypothesis. His breath caught, his grip tightened around the pen, and his face flushed with heat as rage surged through him.
Generated Assessment: His eyes widened in fury, and I could see the redness spreading across his cheeks. He slammed his fist onto the desk, making me jump in surprise. "Who did this?" he demanded, his voice low and even but with an undercurrent of anger. "Did they think it was funny?" I tried to reason with him, explaining that maybe it wasn't intentional, but he wouldn't listen. He kept saying things like, "They're trying to sabotage me" and "This is personal." It seemed like he was already jumping to conclusions about who might have done it, and I worried that he'd overreact before we even knew what happened.

Triggering Event: She's in her lab, alone late at night, when she hears footsteps echoing down the hall. Her heart races as the door creaks open and a familiar face appears - it's her colleague, the one who's been taking credit for her work. He smirks, "Still here, huh? You should learn to let things go." She feels hatred surge through her veins, clenching her fists to keep from slamming something into his smug face.
Generated Assessment: She looks up at him with cold determination, her voice steady but laced with venom, "You think you can just waltz in here and insult me like that?" The words spill out of her mouth before she realizes what she's saying, but she can't take them back now. What if he does something? What if I say something else? What if this is all a setup? What if... what if... what if... But deep down, she knows the truth - she's angry because she thinks he's trying to undermine her. She tries to push those thoughts aside, but they linger in the back of her mind, fueling her anger.

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her retirement home, she overhears a younger nurse laughing with a patient about how they'd never have to care for their spouse after death like some "old widows" did. The bitterness seeps into her veins like poison ivy.
Generated Assessment: She can't stand it anymore; she's fed up with being one of those old women who has spent her life caring for a dying husband until he takes his last breath. It's always been this way - either you're that wife, or you're not. She's done being the second-hand nurse to countless other people's spouses, watching as they get to enjoy life while she's stuck here, holding hands, whispering prayers, and comforting tears. It doesn't help that she heard the young nurse snicker with her patient earlier today. Something about how they'd never have to deal with what she's going through—how they wouldn't be burdened by caring for someone else's loved one until they're nothing but memories—is just too much. Why would anyone want that? But of course, she knows why. Younger generations don't understand the weight of responsibility that comes with loving someone so deeply. They think it's easy to say, "Oh, I'll take care of him," but when the time comes, they'll realize they're no better than her. And then there are those who genuinely love, but it's all in vain because their partner dies first. There's no escape from this curse. As she sits in her rocking chair, she thinks about all the years of sacrifice, all the times she had to put her own needs aside. All the sleepless nights and endless worry over whether everything was okay. How could it be fair? Life isn't fair

Triggering Event: She noticed him, her manager, laughing too loudly with the new girl at the register. The same laugh he used to share with her during their breaks. A sharp pain pierced her chest as she remembered their shared jokes now turned into foreign syllables. Her grip tightened around the mop handle, knuckles turning white. She'd been here for decades, and this was how they repaid her loyalty? A bitter taste rose in her throat. She decided then that they would pay.
Generated Assessment: She felt like a piece of garbage when the new girl accidentally knocked over a plant near the office entrance. It wasn't just an accident; it was a deliberate attempt to humiliate her. She could almost see the smile on his face as he chuckled at her misfortune. Why did everyone have to treat her like dirt now? They were supposed to be her friends, but they'd all forgotten about her. When she tried to speak up, no one even bothered to listen. They just laughed louder, enjoying every moment of her embarrassment. She couldn’t take it anymore—she needed to make them feel the way they made her feel. She had had enough of being treated like this.
